body.p: Rochester, Sunday, 3rd of Iyar (May), 1857.
A voice announcing on the mountains,
peace, peace to him who is far and
to him who is near, saith the Lord,
and to my loyal friend and dearly
beloved, the honored sir, a prince
and a humanitarian, choice spirit,
a man of understanding, learned in
all knowledge, searcher in language
and book, Eliesar Isaac, may his
name shine before the sun.
Honored friend:

Although I intend to undertake, during the course of the next win-
ter, God willing, a new, corrected, and improved edition of my Hebrew gram-
-mar, nevertheless I should like to get rid of the remainder of the former
edition. I have therefore lowered its price to $1.25. Have the goodness,
therefore, and enclose the advertisement here contained, in your worthy
journal, and I shall be very grateful to you if you can do something for
me in this regard.
Moreover, will you please send me 6 of your catechisms.

There is no news. What do you think of the Baltimorean Christian
Sabbath? This is the end of all reformers. One begins with the Te-kum
Purkan and one ends with the removal of the heavenly yoke. But this is
the greatest advantage that orthodoxy can contain, for by this the eyes
of Israel will be opened, and he who dwells in heaven will laugh. Let
them do what they like. There is a time for everything and there is no
man who does not have his hour. I am firmly convinced that within hardly
ten years reform will be as despised as dirt and vomit and the abominations
will depart from this land. What do you say, my friend, that the false
has ceased from Zion? Would that be a calamity??. How has the daugh-
ter of Zion fallen from Heaven? May all their work be thus vain and void.
They shall build and I shall destroy, saith the Lord. What will the great
eagle/who soars over the impure nests of the city of New York do now? Not
in vain did the starling go to the raven, for they are a kind. Each bird
will dwell with its kind, and each man with one who is like him. Have you

also heard about the Emer Habazeleth (Valley of Lilies—Lilienthal) in
Cincinnati, for his odor is gone and evaporated, and he has become like
a bare ruin in the desert.

In the hope that these lines will find you in the best of health
and hoping that you will be a bit disposed to do something about my gram-
mar, I greet you respectfully and say to you, Peace.
Mayer, son of Moses
N.B.

Before Passover, I held a public school examination which met with
everyone's approval. There was also an exhibition which more than
500 persons, mostly Americans of the highest circles here, witnessed.
I also preached on the first and second day of Passover., the Saturday
of Passover and the seventh and last days. The last I did purposely
so that the second day should not seem insignificant to them. I assure
you that our synagogue was full and crowded on each day, the first and
second day and the seventh and last day, in spite of the bad weather and
snow storms. I can say in the words of the Haftarah of the second day
of Passover, “Never has such a Passover been celebrated here” in every
respect. My congregation has already reelected me at a higher salary
long before the expiration of my term. So much for today-more later.
Your friend,
